slidelink.displaytext: Changes in the Brain after Birth
Stages and Milestones of Brain Development
How Does Experience Change the Actual Structure of the Brain?
Environment Contribution to a Child’s Brain Development

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
Welcome to the Developing Brain course.

This course will help you gain an insight into the development and working of a child’s brain from birth till the age of five. It will help you understand why and how babies respond to different situations in the manner that they do. The course also gives you tips on how to handle children for the first three critical years, so as to enable their healthy overall development.

By the end of this course, you will be able to:

·Describe the basic structure of the human brain
·Understand how children’s brains develop in the initial years
·State the importance of environment contribution to a child's brain development, and
·Apply the basic concepts of brain science to understand challenging behavior in children

Every baby is born with 8 billion neurons - the brain cells - ready to meet the world and its challenges. The neurons serve as the basic raw material of the brain.

The construction and development of a child’s brain is an ongoing process, influenced by genetics as well as early experiences.

Scientists have found that the brain is full of circuits between different regions. More than 383 brain regions, 6602 cross-region high-ways and countless local connections have been discovered, built mostly during the first five years of life. The total length of the connection is about one million kilometers, or 50 times the round trip between Los Angeles and Shanghai.

Click the Play icon to watch the video.

Dr. Paul Maclean, a leading neuroscientist, developed the Triune Brain theory to understand the evolution of the brain. According to this theory, the human brain consists of three parts, with multiple neuro pathways through which they influence each other. These are:

·Reptile Brain - which looks after basic functions such as hunger and sleep
·Mammalian Brain - which controls emotions, and
·Rational Brain - which helps to think and make decisions

Click the Play icon to watch the video.

Let us now look at the brain’s sensory driven information processing system.

The senses drive information input to the brain. After the brain processes the information, it drives body parts accordingly, such as focusing sight, moving the mouth to cry, etc. In the mean time, certain information gets to the storage (memory).

Brain science has found that letting children choose what they want to do and how to do it stimulates the Dopamine (neuro-transmitter) to enhance the interaction between the information processing unit and the memory.

Each region of the brain receives information from different senses. These are:

·Visual, which is the sense of sight
·Auditory, which is the sense of hearing
·Olfactory, which is the sense of smell
·Gustative, which is the sense of taste, and
·Somatosensory, which is the sense of touch

In addition, there is the Vestibular Sense, for balance and equilibium, and the Proprioceptive Sense, for muscles and joints.

The vestibular system, which contributes to balance in most mammals and to the sense of spatial orientation, is the sensory system that contribution significantly to movement and sense of balance.

The vestibular System is critical to a baby’s development, as it controls the ability of the baby to respond to gravity and changes in movement. It also impacts the baby’s balance and motor-control tasks such as sitting unsupported, standing, and walking. For example, newborns wake up when you put them down after rocking, due to their Vestibular sensitivity.

Proprioception is the muscle and joint sense, which allows for automatic body movements without having to rely on vision, such as being able to walk up a flight of stairs in the dark. The proprioceptive sense provides information to children about the force needed for routine tasks such as manipulating moving parts on a toy.

Proprioceptive awareness also help in oral motor skills, as children cannot visually monitor their performance and require input from muscles and joints in the mouth.

Proprioceptive input helps maintain and regulate body functions, including healthy neuromuscular and cardiovascular systems.

Children need increasing amounts of physical activity to stay calm and alert throughout their day and proprioceptive activities are a wonderful form of stimulation for calming and organizing the nervous system.

Let us now look at the changes that occur in the human brain after birth.

After birth, there is a massive burst of synaptic formation, known as the exuberant period. The cerebral cortex produces most of its synaptic connections in this period, reaching up to two million new synapses every second at its peak.

These are the connections that drive most of a baby's mental milestones, such as color vision or a pincer grasp.
MRI scans of the brain reveal that the synaptic connections grow over time in a healthy child.

The development of a baby’s brain and its various expressions, from birth through till the age of three, is a period of rapid change, growth, discovery and learning, both for the baby and the caregivers.

The brain develops in stages, and the ability to process information - by Reptilian, Mamalian or Rational Brain - develops with a specific Windows of Opportunity.

Though the pace and nature of development varies with each child, there are broad milestones to look out for at different stages.

Click each time span to know more.

Motor skills are related to sensory input and information processing, and develop early after the birth. The major development for babies in this facet involves coping with gravity at various stages of development.

At 3 to 6 months, the baby learns to cope with the gravity by using the spine to hold the head.

At 8 to 9 months, the baby solidifies the emotional attachment to the primary caregiver, getting ready to explore the world by starting to crawl, thereby moving from a non-mobile to a mobile world.

At 12 to 15 months, the baby learns to hold the balance and walk.

The three segments of the brain function relate to each other: an issue with sensory integration slows down motor skills, which then affects emotional well-being, which in turn may delay language development.

The different segments of the brain function relate to each other: an issue with sensory integration slows down motor skills, which then affects emotional well-being, which may, in turn, delay language development.

Each child’s unique experience formulates his brain circuit. Every experience, be it reading a book or a first go on a swing, excites certain neural circuits whilst leaving others inactive.

Circuits that are consistently activated strengthen over time. Those that are unused get eliminated, thereby streamlining a child’s neural processing and making the remaining circuits work more quickly and efficiently.

Without such synaptic pruning, children would not develop the ability to walk, talk, or even see properly.

Each environmental interaction, whether geographical, cultural, family, school or peer-group, helps fine-tune the neural connections in a child’s brain. Whilst genes specify the number of networks within the brain, it is experience that specifies the finer branches of these connections between.

Click the image to see an example of environmental influence.

Let us now explore the process of sensory integration.

The brain is constantly bombarded with sensory information in all forms, from which the brain selects relevant information through a filtering process.

The information is registered, processed and understood in relation to previous experience in order for an output response or behavior to be generated. Output responses are further modified or modulated through feedback and interpretation. Over time this establishes a base for anticipation of an outcome and appropriate modification or changes.

The functions of the brain can be categorized into three areas:

·Sensory Input, requiring integrated sensory function
·Information processing, which relates to the basic reflex, emotional behavior and the degree of control from Rational Brain, and
·Motor skills, which involve driving body parts such as speech, gesture, movement

Sensory stimulation from the environment needs to be interpreted in an integrated manner. Sensory processing problems, which impact development, information processing, and behavior, can occur at various levels of processing, including:

·Registration
·Modulation, and
·Integration

Click each tab to learn more.

Complex behavior and learning must be considered in relation to a large number of related prerequisite skills. Sensory information forms the foundation to the building blocks of behavior and learning.

When the foundation is not solid, the information processing channels are impeded. This impacts learning, which ultimately impacts adaptive behavior and complex or integrated skills.

Sensory processing disorders (SPD) refer to the inability of the nervous system to read and coordinate information/input received via touch, pressure, sound, vision, and movement. Children with SPD exhibit odd behaviors such as not wanting to be touched, or conversely, wanting to be held continuously.

A test conducted in 2006 by May-Benson, Koomar, & Teasdale, revealed that 42% of children with SPD had difficulties at the stage of pregnancy labor or delivery.

Click the tab for more details about the test results.

Sensory processing disorders can be prevented through systematic exercises, or at least diagnosed in the early years for an early intervention.

·At 7-8 months, environment feedback, in the form of a close and warm interaction with the baby, helps stabilize the mammalian brain.
·After the baby starts to walk, the rational brain begins to develop, facilitating self and environmental awareness, logical sense, and creativity.

Consider these situations.

Linda, 22 months, insists on climbing the swing at the park by herself even as her dad warns her not to.

Brian, 30 months, refuses to have his cereal unless he’s allowed chocolate first.

When toddlers and young children begin to understand that they are separate from the parents and can exert some control over their world, they tend to oppose and disobey parents. Defiance is a powerful method of asserting individuality.

Aggressive behavior is another challenge in handling toddlers. Babies often do things that appear and feel aggressive, like biting or taking a swing at you, but its because they are not yet able to control their feelings or use words to communicate.

In slightly older children, those between 2 and 3 years of age, aggression may more commonly be seen in the form of fights with siblings and friends or other tantrums.

Over time, most children understand and learn to respect rules which are laid down about aggressive behavior.
However, here are some guidelines to deal with aggressive behavior in toddlers:

·Recognize and validate your child’s goal.
·Use gestures along with words to communicate.
·Offer your child other alternatives or, if very young, a distraction.

Dave, aged 9 weeks, seems to cry most in the evening. Feeding helps to calm him down sometimes and a walk works on occasions. But sometimes nothing seems to soothe him and Dave’s mother find herself getting highly irritable at around bedtime each day, wondering what his problem is.

Why do you think Dave cries so much?

Crying is the most normal way for babies to communicate any kind of discomfort, be it hunger, distress, or a need for your attention. A normal crying pattern would have a crying peak at about 6 weeks and a gradual tapering off after that.

Some babies, however, cry more than others and might have a condition known as colic. This involves crying that begins and ends for no obvious reason for least 3 hours a day, lasting at least 3 days a week, for a period ranging from 3 weeks to 3 months.
Temperament is a major influence on how a child approaches and reacts to the world. It the child’s personal "style” and is a key factor in understanding their behavior and interaction with others.

The environment gives a child the feedback to activate or deactivate certain part of the brain circuit. Thus a child’s social emotional and cognitive behaviors are “molded” by the environment where he or she lives in - interaction with parents, siblings, relatives, teachers, friends etc.

Click the tab to see examples of child behavior molded by the environment.

Congratulations! You have now reached the end of this course.

Let’s summarize the points we have covered.

·The first five years of a baby’s life see rapid growth in every facet of development.
·The development of a child’s brain is an ongoing process, influenced by genetics but especially early experiences.
·The human brain multiple neuro pathways through which the human brain processes the received information.
·Besides the traditional five senses, humans have also the Vestibular Sense and the Proprioceptive Sense.
·Each sense functions independently, and together, to deliver information to the brain for processing.
·Sensory Processing Disorders (SPD) are the cause for many behavioral issues as well as learning disabilities.
·Preventive exercises , practiced from birth, can assist sensory Integration and provide early diagnosis.
·Each environmental interaction helps fine-tune the neural connections in a child’s brain.
·The environmental interaction shall however be timed with each child’s developmental stages not too early nor too late.
·Challenging behavior in young children can take on various expressions, such as aggression, defiance and colic crying.
·Temperament is a key factor in children’s behavior and interaction with others.
·These challenging behaviors can be prevented through a systematic exercise and learning process, focusing on brain processing of the information.

Now that you have completed the course, it’s time to test what you have learned.

There are three questions in this assessment. Each question carries equal marks. There is no negative marking. The passing percentage for this assessment is 65. So you need to answer at least two questions correctly to clear the assessment. There is no time limit, so you can take your time to consider each question carefully before attempting.

Please note that while taking the assessment, you cannot return to the previous question or move to the next one without attempting the current question.

Click Start to begin the assessment.

Good Luck!

Navigation in this course is simple and easy.

Click the marker of each button to view its description.
